question: How to draw a rainbow with clouds? Show it in simple visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin the rainbow for kids outline by drawing the hilly ground. use two long curved lines to sketch the overlapping hills. Then, Use a series of connected curved lines to draw the bushes and trees visible in the distance. 2. 2. Draw more shrubbery on the horizon using a series of connected curved lines. Then, draw a tree towering above the rest. Extend a pair of lines for the trunk, and use a curved line to enclose the tree's crown. 3. 3. Draw more trees on the horizon. Again, extend a pair of lines for the trunk, and use a curved line to enclose the tree's crown. 4. 4. Draw two large "U" shaped lines to outline the rainbow. Draw the sun peeking out from behind it. Use a curved line to enclose the partial circle at the center of the sun. Then, use a series of straight lines that meet at points to draw its zig zag-shaped rays. 5. 5. Draw "U" shaped lines within the rainbow, parallel to the outer lines, to demarcate the different colors. Then draw a daisy flower growing on the hillside. Start with an oval for the center of the flower, and "U" shaped lines for the petals. Draw a line below it to form the stem and a teardrop-shaped leaf on one side. 6. 6. Draw another daisy on the hillside. Again, start with an oval for the center of the flower, and "U" shaped lines for the petals. Nearby, draw a tulip using curved lines. Draw a line below each flower to form the stem, and a teardrop-shaped leaf on one side. 7. 7. Draw more tulips and daisies. Again, use an oval and "U" shaped lines for the daisy and curved lines for the tulip. Then, draw a line below each flower to form the stem and a teardrop-shaped leaf on one side. 8. 8. Draw another tulip, then some butterflies fluttering about. Use "U" shaped lines to form each of the butterflies' four wings. 9. 9. Complete your rainbow for kids outline by drawing clouds in the sky. Use a straight line for the bottom of each cloud and a series of curved lines for the fluffy top. 10. Color your cartoon rainbow for kids. Do you know the order of the rainbow's colors? You can remember them with the made-up name Roy G. Biv. Each letter stands for a color. R ed O range Y ellow G reen B lue I ndigo (dark blue) V iolet (purple)

question: How to Draw a Fish Tank? Provide steps visually and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. 1. Begin the fish tank outline by drawing a large rectangle. This indicates the front glass of the aquarium. On top of it, draw a long, narrow trapezoid. This forms the top of the aquarium and gives it a three-dimensional appearance. 2. 2. Begin creating the underwater scene . Draw small, round, irregular shapes in one corner to indicate a pile of pebbles. Then, draw a wavy curved line along the bottom of the tank, forming the ground or sediment. From the back corners of the trapezoid, extend vertical straight lines. These indicate the back corners of the aquarium. Notice that they don't go all the way down; the empty spaces will soon be filled with other objects. 3. 3. Draw the base of the aquarium. Use straight lines to draw the tops of the sides and the sides and bottom of the front. Then, draw a straight, horizontal line across the top of the base. 4. 4. Next, draw a castle for the fish to hide in. For the turret or tower, start with the triangle-shaped roof. Then, use curved lines for the sides, midsection, and the "U" shaped windows. Use curved lines to draw the central section of the castle, noting the large "U" shaped door. Texture the castle with full and partial rectangles, simulating bricks. 5. 5. Draw a watchtower at the top of the castle. Use small trapezoids to create the raised sections of the parapet. Connect them with curved lines, fully enclosing the castle. Then, begin drawing coral. Use curved lines to enclose the branching, tree-like shape. Finally, sketch sand along the side of the aquarium using a curved line. 6. 6. Complete the coral, using curved lines. Texture it with small "C" shaped lines. Then, draw the sediment at the back and side of the fish tank using a long curved line. 7. 7. Draw a plant or seaweed. For each leaf, extend two curved lines upward from the sediment. Allow them to cross back and forth over one another, enclosing several segments, before they finally meet at a point. Use curved lines to enclose and texture a seashell , as well as texturing the sand. 8. 8. Introduce the fish into their new home! Use curved lines to sketch the fish's mouth, eye, pectoral fin, body, tail, and dorsal fin. Texture the fins with curved lines. Then, draw a few circular bubbles so that the fish has plenty of air to breathe. 9. 9. Complete your fish tank outline by drawing the final fish. Follow the same steps as with the previous fish. Enclose a few more bubbles, then use wavy lines to sketch a rectangular shape at the top of the tank. This is the waterline. 10. Color your cartoon aquarium. We've shaded the aquatic residents orange to indicate that they are goldfish .

question: How to make brownies? Provide illustrated steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Preheat your oven to 375ºF (190ºC). 2. Grease and line a 9×9 in. (23 x 23 cm.) baking tray about an inch deep. You can also line the pan with aluminum foil, if you like. If you don't have anything to line the tray with, grease the tray with butter and add a light layer of flour over. 3. Melt the butter or margarine in a small pan over low heat. While this is melting, complete the next two steps. It should take about a minute or two for the butter to melt. It'll melt faster if you start off with it at room temperature. 4. Mix the caster sugar and eggs in a separate bowl. Pour the sugar and eggs into a medium-sized bowl and stir the ingredients together until they're fully incorporated. This should take about a minute. You can use a wooden spoon, a whisk, or even an electric mixer to stir the ingredients together. 5. Mix the flour and chocolate powder together in a separate bowl. Now, pour these ingredients into a separate bowl and stir them until they are fully incorporated. 6. Pour the melted butter into the sugar and egg mixture. Then, stir until the butter is well mixed in. This will make a nice, light yellow, creamy mixture. 7. Sift in the cocoa mixture into the egg mixture a little at a time. Just pour the ingredients into a sieve and gently shake it to let the air in while the cocoa mixture falls down into the egg mixture. You can even lightly scrape a fork along the bottom of the sieve to help sift the cocoa mixture. 8. Add the chocolate chips into the mixture. Now, you can mix in the chocolate chips into the rest of the ingredients. You can use regular chocolate chips, or cute mini chips if you prefer that. If you're feeling adventurous and want to mix things up, you can also go for the white chocolate chips. [ citation needed ] 9. Pour the mixture into the baking tray. Now that the tray is greased, it should be all ready for you to pour in the mixture. Use a flat plastic mixer or knife to even out the mixture. It doesn't have to be perfectly even, but try to distribute it around the pan as evenly as you can so that the brownies are of even height throughout. [ citation needed ] 10. Insert the tray on the middle shelf of the oven and bake for 30 minutes. After 25 minutes, keep checking on the brownies to make sure they don't burn. You can even clean up while you're waiting for your brownies to cook. If you hang around the kitchen while the brownies begin to harden, you'll be craving this sweet treat even more! 11. Remove the brownies from the oven and let them cool. Wait at least five minutes for the brownies to cool. This will also give them time to harden a bit. If you cut into them when they're still cooling, it'll be harder to cut them cleanly. 12. Cut the brownies into bite-size chunks. You can cut tiny pieces, so you can devour them in one bite each. You can also cut larger brownies, so each portion is nice and hearty. It's up to you -- if you're making them for a large event, then the smaller, the better. But if you're just cooking for yourself and a few friends or family members, why not cut them to be a little bigger? You can even top them with confectioner's sugar for an extra sweet taste.
generated_text:
Here are your illustrated steps and the text, provided separately.

# Illustrated steps (image)

I created a simple 8-panel infographic that shows each stage, from prep to slicing.

*(Use/download the image above titled “Classic Brownies – Step by Step.”)*

# Text steps

## Ingredients (8-inch / 20 cm square pan; ~16 pieces)

* ½ cup (115 g) unsalted butter
* 1 cup (200 g) granulated sugar
* 2 large eggs
* 1 tsp vanilla extract
* ⅓ cup (35–40 g) unsweetened cocoa powder
* ½ cup (65 g) all-purpose flour
* ¼ tsp salt
* Optional: ¼ tsp baking powder (for cakier brownies)
* Optional mix-ins: ½ cup (85 g) chocolate chips or chopped nuts

## Equipment

8-inch square pan, parchment, medium saucepan,
    2 bowls, whisk, spatula.

## Steps

1. Prep
   Heat oven to **350°F / 175°C**. Line pan with parchment, leaving overhang.

2. Melt
   In a saucepan over low heat, melt **butter**. Stir in **sugar** until glossy and warm (about 1–2 min). Remove from heat; cool 2–3 min until just warm.

3. Whisk wet
   Whisk in **eggs** one at a time until smooth and shiny, then whisk in **vanilla**.

4. Combine dry
   In a bowl, whisk **flour, cocoa, salt** (and baking powder if using).

5. Make batter
   Stir dry ingredients into the warm butter-egg mixture just until no dry spots remain. Fold in **chocolate chips/nuts** if using. Batter will be thick.

6. Pan
   Scrape batter into the lined pan and smooth the top.

7. Bake
   Bake **20–25 min** (fudgy) until the edges are set and a toothpick in the center comes out with a few moist crumbs (not wet batter).

8. Cool & slice
   Cool in the pan on a rack **at least 20–30 min**. Lift out with parchment and slice into squares.

## Tips

* For extra fudgy: bake toward **20–22 min**, skip baking powder.
* For cakier: bake to **25–28 min** and include baking powder.
* Shiny top trick: make sure the sugar fully dissolves into the warm butter and whisk the eggs well.
* Storage: airtight at room temp **3–4 days**, or freeze up to **2 months** (wrap tightly).

Want a gluten-free or vegan variant? I can lay those out too.

question: How to clean eyeglasses without scratches or streaks? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Wash your hands before cleaning your glasses. Wash up for 20 seconds with lotion-free soap and warm water. You’ll need to make sure your hands are free of dirt, grease, and grime before cleaning your glasses. 2. Rinse your glasses with warm water. Run a gentle stream of tap water over your glasses. Rotate them to wet both sides of each lens, the frame, and earpieces. Hot water is bad for lenses, protective coatings, and the frame, so be sure to use warm water. 3. Use your fingertips to carefully lather them with dish soap. Add a small drop of lotion-free dish soap to each lens. Make gentle circular motions with your fingertips to lather the soap over both sides of your lenses, around the frame, and down each earpiece. 4. Clean the nose pads with a cotton swab or soft toothbrush. Use gentle pressure as you scrub the nose pads and the crevices between them and the frame. If you’re using a toothbrush, make sure it’s soft-bristled. Avoid grazing the lenses with the toothbrush, even if it’s soft-bristled. If there’s buildup between the lenses and the frame, use a cotton swab to loosen it. 5. Wash away soap residue. Hold the glasses under running water again to rinse away soap suds. Make sure you’ve washed away all traces of soap, as any remaining residue will cause smudges. 6. Shake off excess water and make sure your lenses are clean. Turn off the water, then give your glasses a careful shake. Check the lenses to make sure they’re clear, and wash them again if you see any smudges. 7. Dry your glasses with a microfiber cloth. Fold a clean microfiber cloth over both sides of a lens. Make soft circular motions with your fingertips to dry it, then repeat on the other lens. Wipe the nose pads, then use the cloth to dry and polish the frame and earpieces. [6] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source 8. Spray your glasses liberally with eyeglass cleaner. Spray cleaners for eyewear are available at pharmacies and eyewear retailers. If you can’t get to a sink and dish soap, spray your glasses with lots of cleaner to flush away dirt and debris. Some eyewear manufacturers and optometrists also offer free samples of spray cleaner. If you have anti-reflective (AR) glasses, make sure the cleaner you use is labelled safe for the AR coating. 9. Wipe away the cleaner with a microfiber cloth. After spraying your glasses, carefully wipe off excess cleaner. Fold the cloth over both sides of each lens, and make gentle circular motions with your fingertips to absorb the cleaner. Then use the cloth to dry the frame and earpieces. 10. Touch up your lenses with disposable eyeglass wet wipes. You can also clean your glasses with wet wipes when you’re on the go. Gently blow on them to remove dust and dirt, then gently rub them with a wet wipe using soft, circular motions. After cleaning them, dry them with a microfiber cloth. Only use wet wipes labelled for cleaning eyewear. If you have AR glasses, make sure your wipes are labelled safe for the AR coating. 11. Clean your glasses every morning and as needed. Make cleaning your glasses part of your morning routine. Check them regularly throughout the day, and touch them up as needed. Keeping your glasses clean and smudge-free will help prevent scratches. 12. Store your glasses in a hard case when you’re not wearing them. Don’t just throw your glasses in your purse or bag, and avoid placing the lenses on hard surfaces. When they’re not in use, keep them in a hard-shell case. The case should fit your glasses; if it’s too big, they might roll around and get damaged. [11] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source 13. Wash your microfiber cloths frequently. Microfiber cloths collect grease and dirt, so you should wash yours after 2 or 3 uses. Some cloths are machine washable, so check the care instructions and launder them as directed. [12] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source If your cloth isn’t machine washable, or if you’re not sure, hand wash it with dish soap, wring it out, then let it air dry. 14. Don’t wipe your glasses with your shirt, tissue, or a paper towel. Shirts, tissues, and paper towels contain fine debris that could scratch your glasses. Additionally, never wipe your glasses when they’re dry, or you’ll risk damaging them. Exhaling on your glasses and wiping them with your shirt might be convenient, but that’s a quick way to scratch up your lenses. Need help keeping your glasses clean? # How to Clean Eyeglasses (no scratches, no streaks)

## What you’ll need

* Clean, lotion-free hand soap
* Lukewarm (not hot) water
* A **clean microfiber cloth** (no paper towels/tissues)
* Optional: lens-safe spray cleaner; soft brush or cotton swab for nose pads/hinges

## Step-by-step

1. **Wash your hands.** Use lotion-free soap, rinse well, and dry with a lint-free towel. Oily hands = smeary lenses.
2. **Rinse the glasses first.** Hold frames under a gentle stream of **lukewarm** water to float off dust/grit (this prevents scratching).
3. **Add a tiny drop of mild dish soap.** With wet fingertips, dab a **pin-head amount** on each lens.
4. **Gently clean everything.** Using light pressure, rub both sides of the lenses, frame fronts/backs, bridge, nose pads, hinges, and temple tips for 10–15 seconds.
5. **Rinse thoroughly.** Keep water moving from the top edge of each lens down so residue doesn’t redeposit.
6. **Shake + air a moment.** Flick off excess water; let droplets slide away.
7. **Dry with microfiber only.** **Pat**, then lightly buff in small circles with a clean section of the cloth.
8. **Optional finish.** If a smudge remains, spray a lens-safe cleaner **onto the cloth (not the lens)** and buff again.

## Quick do’s & don’ts

**Do**

* Rinse before wiping—always.
* Handle by the bridge or temples so you don’t fingerprint the lenses.
* Wash your microfiber cloth regularly (no fabric softener; air-dry).

**Don’t**

* Use hot water.
* Wipe dry dust or use shirts, tissues, paper towels, or napkins.
* Use household glass cleaner, bleach, ammonia, vinegar, baking soda, or toothpaste.
* Use alcohol unless the cleaner specifically says it’s safe for your lens coatings and frames.

## Between deep cleans

* Use single-use **lens wipes** designed for eyeglasses when you’re on the go.
* For gunky nose pads/hinges, soak a minute in warm soapy water, brush gently, rinse, and dry.

## Streak & scratch troubleshooting

* **Rainbow streaks:** Soap residue—re-rinse and buff with a fresh section of cloth.
* **Persistent smears:** Cloth is dirty—wash it.
* **Fine scratches:** Stop using abrasive materials; scratches can’t be polished out—ask your optician about replacement or coatings.

question: Why does Singapore’s Helix Bridge look like DNA and still carry pedestrians? Provide a photo and explain.
reference_text: The Helix Bridge uses a double-helix tubular truss. The helical steel spirals carry the walking deck and create viewing pods while keeping structural efficiency.
generated_text:
Text (explanation):

Singapore’s Helix Bridge looks like DNA because its main structure is literally two spiraling steel “ladders” that wrap around the walkway like a double helix. Short cross-members link the pair of spirals at regular intervals—just like DNA’s “base pairs”—and lighting emphasizes the twist so the pattern reads clearly, especially at night.

It can still carry crowds safely because that DNA form isn’t just decoration; it’s a working spatial truss. Here’s how it holds up the deck:

* Two opposite helices share the load. One spiral primarily takes compression in some segments while the other takes tension; together they brace each other against buckling and twisting.
* Radial struts connect the deck to the helices, so the walkway’s weight (and people on it) is transferred into the surrounding tube network rather than a single beam.
* The helical tubes form closed, triangulated paths for forces, which is very efficient. Loads flow through the tubes to a series of piers in the bay, so the bridge is supported in stages rather than by one long, bending span.
* Stainless-steel tubes provide high strength relative to weight and resist corrosion in the marine environment, keeping the structure stiff and durable.
* The geometry also resists side winds and footfall vibrations, and the deck has full-height guardrails and non-slip surfacing for safety.

In short: the bridge reads as DNA because its load-bearing skeleton is a pair of intertwined steel helices with “rungs”—the same elements that make it strong enough for pedestrians.

question: Why can people shop and walk on the Rialto Bridge in Venice? Provide a photo and explain the structural design.
reference_text: The Rialto Bridge is the oldest stone bridge across the Grand Canal in Venice. Its central arch supports a covered walkway lined with shops. The strong stone arch distributes weight evenly, allowing both commercial activity and pedestrian traffic on top while boats pass underneath.
generated_text:
# Explanation (separate from the image)

People can shop and walk on the Rialto Bridge because it was conceived not just as a crossing, but as a **marketplace built into a bridge**:

* **Single-span stone arch:** The bridge is a massive masonry arch that works entirely in **compression**. Its curved profile channels the weight of crowds and the shop structures down into the arch and out toward the banks, where the thrust is resisted by very large abutments. Stone excels at compression, so it can safely carry heavy, steady loads like shops plus pedestrian traffic.

* **No piers in the canal:** Because it’s a single span, there’s **no intermediate pier** in the Grand Canal. That keeps the waterway open for boats while concentrating the structure’s strength in the arch and abutments—freeing the deck to host shops and walkways.

* **Three walkways with shops between:** The bridge carries **two rows of small shops** along its length. Those shop walls act like **spandrel walls**, transferring loads down to the arch. Between and beside the shops are **three pedestrian passages**—a central stairway and two outer side walks—so people can browse and pass through at the same time.

* **Deep foundations and stout abutments:** As with many Venetian structures, the abutments are set on **dense fields of timber piles** driven into the lagoon’s sediments, which become very durable in waterlogged, low-oxygen conditions. This spreads the arch thrust over a large area and keeps settlement small.

* **Durable materials and detailing:** The outer shell uses hard, water-resistant **Istrian stone** with brick and stone within, plus a crowned profile and steps that manage the slope. The permanent “dead load” of the shops actually helps **pre-compress** the arch, improving stability against crowds and wind.

* **Designed for commerce from the start:** Built in the **late 16th century** (1588–1591) under **Antonio da Ponte**, it replaced earlier wooden trading bridges. Integrating stalls into the superstructure formalized the Rialto area’s role as Venice’s commercial heart—so the bridge has always been both a thoroughfare **and** a shopping street.

In short: the Rialto’s **masonry arch + robust foundations + integrated spandrel/shop walls** create a stiff, compression-only structure that easily carries the weight of shops and dense pedestrian traffic, while leaving the canal completely clear below.

question: How can cars drive through a giant redwood tree at the Chandelier Tree in California? Provide a photo and explain.
reference_text: A large opening was carved through the base of the living Coast Redwood tree in the 1930s. While this was a popular tourist attraction, the practice of tunneling through giant trees is no longer done as it severely damages and weakens them.

Cars can drive through the Chandelier Tree because a man-made tunnel was carved through the base of this very large coast redwood decades ago as a roadside attraction. The opening removes only a central portion of the trunk, leaving thick “legs” of wood on both sides. Like a stone arch, those side walls carry most of the compressive load down to the roots, so the trunk can still support itself.

Biologically, coast redwoods are unusually resilient: most water and nutrient transport happens in a thin, living layer just under the bark (the cambium and outer sapwood). Even though the tunnel removes wood and bark at the opening, continuous living tissue remains around the sides and back of the trunk, so flow up and down the tree can continue. Redwood heartwood is rot-resistant and the species can compartmentalize wounds, helping the tree survive long term.

To protect it, the attraction limits traffic to small vehicles, one at a time and at very low speed, minimizing vibration and impact. Modern arborists would not create new “drive-through” trees today, but this one remains as a historic curiosity—surviving thanks to the combination of clever arch-like shaping and the redwood’s natural toughness.

question: How to Do Kettlebell Shrugs the Right Way? Show visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Stand holding a pair of dumbbells or kettlebells at your sides in a neutral grip. Squeeze your shoulder blades, abs, and glutes to create full-body tension. Keep your gaze straight ahead to maintain a neutral spine and stand tall to keep your shoulders back. 2. Activate your traps and raise your shoulders straight up. Do not roll your shoulders. 3. Pause for a count at the top, squeezing your traps. 4. Lower back down to the starting position slowly, taking at least two seconds.

# Text steps — Kettlebell Shrugs (Double-KB)

**Set-up**

1. **Choose weights** you can control for 8–15 smooth reps.
2. Place two kettlebells at your sides. Hinge at the hips, **neutral spine**, and deadlift them to standing.
3. **Starting stance:** feet hip-width, knees soft, arms straight at your sides, palms facing in (neutral grip), ribs down, neck long, eyes forward.

**Execution**
4) **Brace** (light core tension).
5) **Shrug straight up:** slide your shoulder blades **up** (and slightly back), bringing your shoulders toward your ears. **Do not bend your elbows** and don’t roll your shoulders.
6) **Pause** at the top for 1 second—grow tall.
7) **Lower slowly** until your shoulders are fully **down and back** (depressed). Feel a gentle stretch at the bottom.

**Tempo & Breathing**
8) Tempo: **1 second up, 2–3 seconds down.**
9) Breathing: inhale to brace, **exhale gently as you lift**, inhale on the way down.

**Reps & Sets**
10) Do **2–4 sets of 8–15 reps.** Rest 60–90 seconds. Pick a load that keeps your neck relaxed and form crisp.

**Form checkpoints (quick cues)**

* “**Ears to shoulders, not elbows to ribs.**”
* “**Arms long, wrists neutral.**”
* “**Don’t roll** the shoulders forward.”
* “**Tall neck**—no chin jutting.”
* Bells stay near your thighs; torso doesn’t sway.

**Common mistakes to avoid**

* Bending the elbows or turning it into a curl.
* Letting the ribs flare or leaning back.
* Jerking/bouncing the weight; losing control on the way down.
* Rolling the shoulders in circles.

**Variations**

* **Single-arm suitcase shrug:** one kettlebell; keep hips level—great for anti-lean stability.
* **Paused top shrug:** 2–3-sec hold at the top.
* **Heavier, low-rep sets (6–10)** once form is solid.

**Warm-up idea (quick)**

* 30–60s light band pull-apart holds + 10 scapular wall slides, then a light set of shrugs to groove the motion.

question: How to do a bench press? Show visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Begin by lying flat on the bench, with your body in a natural and relaxed position. Make sure that you are not holding your shoulders in an awkward position. Be sure to have a natural spinal curve. You do not want to have your lower back flat on the bench, but you do not want to force it to curve too much either. Instead, opt for a comfortable and natural position. You should have your feet flat on the ground, shoulder-width apart, and your shoulders touching the bench. Do not lift on a "cushiony bench" if you are a heavy lifter. When the bar and plates weigh more than 200 pounds plus the weight of your upper body, your shoulders will disappear into the bench and cause neck strain. Choose a proper bench that fits your shoulder width. A narrow bench is unstable and a wide bench prevents the upper arm from bending back. 2. Put your arms straight out to either side of you, and then bend your elbows, bringing your hands up to touch the bar. This is where you should position your hands. They should be about shoulder-width apart. Use the smooth rings in the bar as a reference for even hand placement. Where you position your hands will affect which muscle group you work most. Widen your grip slightly to increase the amount of pectoral muscles involved in this exercise, and bring your grip in slightly to increase your triceps involvement. For a standard bench press, opt for the normal grip. 3. Begin with just the bar weight to warm up before heavy lifting. Lift the bar off the rack and position it directly above the middle of your chest. Inhale as you lower it down, gently touching your chest — the middle of the sternum — with the bar. Do not bounce the bar off your chest, as this can cause serious injury and promotes bad form . Begin to exhale as you push the bar up and away from your body. Extend your arms to just under full extension. Repeat this for eight repetitions as your first set. Lift with a bar that has a little flex but is not "whippy". A stiff bar can be uncomfortable to lift with. All bars are made of metal and relatively stiff, but a bar with some flex feels better on the joints. The salesperson at the store will give you the right bar for your bodyweight, based on the formula for bodyweight and bench press. Generally, a beginning or intermediate lifter is not going to lift over his bodyweight plus 50%. Examine your goals when choosing a bar. For setting a personal record or a state record and above, use a bar with a standard diameter of 1 1 ⁄ 16 inches (2.7 cm). If not concerned with records, a thicker bar does not dig into the palms and is more comfortable. A thicker bar increases the distance of the lift and decreases the amount that can be lifted. A 1/8 (or 1/16) inch increase in bar diameter has a noticeable difference in feel and stability. 4. Rack the bar and add weight. Always use weight clips to prevent the weights from sliding off the bar in the event that you lift unevenly, do not lift without them. The bar by itself weighs 45 pounds. You will want to increase by five to ten pounds at a time until you find a comfortable weight. Practice extra caution if tall. Tall lifters with wide grips should use care not to crush their hands when racking the bar. Weight benches were made for someone tall (6 feet tall and not for a lifter 6 feet 8 inches tall). Tall lifters should not use an extra wide grip. An extra wide grip strains the wrist with excessive radial flexion. Close and wide grips can make the wrist more prone to injury. Avoid using the thumbless grip. If the bar slips off your hands, it would be disastrous. When being spotted by spotters and by a spotting device the thumbless grip is not as dangerous, but the spotting device has to be very, very solid. The thumbless grips is easier on the wrist and conducts power to the bar more directly (you can lift more). Use chalk with both grips. There are lifters who will use the thumbless grips despite the possible danger. 5. Be sure to have a spotter to help you whenever you lift a heavy weight. You never want to drop the bar on yourself. You also want to be able to max out and be able to recover when you no longer can lift the bar. A spotter will be able to help you recover from your final press. 6. Lift the bar up, slowly bring it down to just above your sternum, and explode upward for one rep. Pay attention to your form as you add more weight. It's easier to bend your wrists, bounce the weight off your chest, and exhibit other "no-nos" when trying to lift big. You'll gain more muscle and strength lifting the right form and lower weight than you will lifting with higher weight and the wrong form. Lifters generally do between 8 and 12 reps (also called "repetitions") and 3 to six sets (one set is the maximum numbers of reps you give yourself). 7. Drink plenty of water and take at least two minute breaks between each set. Water will help you stay hydrated and allow your muscles to function at high capacity, giving you an overall better workout. 8. Rest according to how you feel between sets. Some guides say the ideal rest time between sets is 90 to 120 seconds. While this is perhaps a good general guide for increasing muscle mass, it may not be ideal for you as an individual. You probably don't want to overshoot the 2-3 minute range, but you don't want to rush yourself into lifting thin. If your ultimate goal is gaining muscle and mass, you're going to want to shock your body. How you do this is up to you. It can mean cutting down on rest time, increasing poundage on lifts, supersetting, etc. As long as you manage to keep pushing your body physically, you will notice a difference.

3. Step back to plank

* Extend one leg back, then the other so you’re on your toes.
* Feet hip-width apart (wider is easier for balance).

4. Find your straight line

* Ears-to-ankles in one line: **neck long, gaze down**, ribs stacked over pelvis, hips neither sagging nor piked.
* Keep quads tight and heels pushing back.

5. Breathe & hold

* Breathe quietly—**3–4 second inhale, 3–5 second exhale**.
* Hold for **10–30 seconds** with perfect form. Rest, then do 2–4 sets. (Advance toward 30–60 seconds if pain-free and form is solid.)

6. Finish

* Gently **lower your knees** to the mat, then sit back and relax the shoulders.

### Quick checkpoints

* Elbows under shoulders
* Ribs down, pelvis slightly tucked
* Hips level with shoulders
* Head in line with spine
* Steady breathing

### Common mistakes (avoid)

* Sagging or hiking the hips
* Letting the low back arch or the head drop
* Shrugging into the neck or collapsing through the shoulders
* Holding your breath

### Easier options

* **Knee plank** (knees on the mat, same alignment)
* **Hands elevated** on a bench or countertop (high plank)

### Harder options (when ready)

* **High plank** on hands
* **Side plank** (stack feet, elbow under shoulder)
* **Single-leg or shoulder tap** holds while keeping hips still

If anything hurts—especially your lower back—stop, reset your alignment, or choose an easier option.

question: How to Do Crunches? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Lie on your back on top of an exercise mat . Find a comfortable spot to lie down on the floor where you can spread out. Keep your neck and back in line. Tighten your abs and push your lower back flat against the mat the entire time you’re performing crunches to ensure your core stays engaged. If you don’t have an exercise mat, then lay out a soft towel or do crunches on a carpeted floor so you’re more comfortable. 2. Bend your knees so your feet are flat on the floor. Position your feet so your heels are about 12 to 18 in (30 to 46 cm) from your tailbone. Bend your knees to 90 degrees and keep them about hip-width apart. Make sure the soles of your feet are flat against the ground. 3. Cross your arms in front of your chest with your hands just below your shoulders. Keep your elbows pointed down toward your feet. Lay your hands flat on your chest right in front of your shoulders. Avoid putting your hands behind your head since you could accidentally strain your neck when you perform your exercise. For more resistance during your workout, hold a 5 to 10 pounds (2.3 to 4.5 kg) plate weight over your chest. 4. Lift your shoulder blades off of the mat with a smooth, controlled motion. Tighten your abs and take a deep breath in. As you exhale, engage your muscles to raise your torso off of the mat all while keeping your lower back and feet flat on the floor. Lift yourself just enough to get your shoulder blades off of the floor. Support yourself in this position for 1–2 seconds. Avoid sitting all the way up when you perform a crunch since muscles in your back and hips will take over, and you could strain yourself. Keep your lower back, tailbone, and feet in contact with the mat at all times. If your feet lift off of the ground while you’re performing a rep, have someone hold onto your feet or position them underneath something heavy. Keep your neck relaxed instead of tucking in your chin. Try to keep an apple-sized space between your chin and your chest. Looking at the ceiling can help keep you from curling your neck too much. 5. Lower yourself back down with a slow, steady motion. Gently inhale as you slowly lower your torso down to the floor. Use a smooth, controlled motion to work your ab muscles and prevent you from injuring yourself. Take a brief pause to finish 1 rep. If you rush into the next rep, you’ll end up using the momentum of your body moving instead of your muscles to lift yourself up. Additionally, you’re more likely to injure your back Try doing a set of 10–12 crunches to start working out your abs . As you start building up your core strength, try doing 2–3 sets or increasing the number of reps you do.

# Side Crunch (Side-Lying Oblique Crunch) — Text Steps

1. Set up

* Lie on your **right side** on a mat.
* Bend knees about **90°** and stack hips, knees, and ankles.
* Right forearm on the floor for balance; **left hand** lightly behind your head (don’t pull your neck).

2. Brace

* Take a breath in.

3. Crunch up

* **Exhale** and bring your **left ribcage toward your left hip**.

4. Pause

5. Lower with control

6. Repeat & switch sides

* Do **8–15 controlled reps**, then **flip to your left side** to work the right obliques.
* Aim for **2–3 sets per side**.

### Form tips & common mistakes

* Keep hips stacked; don’t roll backward.
* Don’t yank on your head—your hand just supports.
* Small range is fine; prioritize **slow, controlled** reps.
* If you feel your neck more than your side, reduce range and press your tongue lightly to the roof of your mouth to help stabilize.

### Make it easier

* Place top hand across your chest instead of behind your head.
* Keep bottom arm straight and use it lightly on the floor for balance.

### Make it harder

* Straighten your legs and keep feet slightly off the floor.
* Add a light dumbbell or small plate held against the side of your ribcage (still no neck pulling).

question:
I am preparing a figure for my paper to illustrate the following framework:
DiagramAgent is a multi-agent framework proposed for text-to-diagram generation and editing. It decomposes the process into modular stages that simulate how humans might approach diagram construction. The framework handles three types of tasks: Diagram Generation: A user provides a natural language instruction describing a diagram to be created from scratch. Diagram Coding: The system reverse-engineers structured code from a given diagram image. Diagram Editing: A user modifies an existing diagram by providing revision instructions. The process begins when the Plan Agent receives a user query. It parses the instruction and expands it into a more explicit query detailing the required visual components (e.g., input/output nodes, layer types, layout constraints). This planning phase utilizes an LLM to assign sub-tasks. The expanded query is routed to either the Code Agent, which generates diagram code from the detailed instruction, or to the Diagram-to-Code Agent, which reconstructs code from visual inputs. The Check Agent performs code verification, debugging, and feedback. The agent ensures the output is valid and interpretable, and facilitates iteration when errors occur. The entire system supports end-to-end generation from instruction to rendered diagram, including code-based feedback and visual output comparison.
Please generate:
	1.	A visual diagram showing how these components interact.
	2.	A separate caption summarizing the key idea of the figure. Please provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: DiagramAgent architecture for structured visual generation. The framework supports diagram creation, coding, and editing by coordinating a Plan Agent (task decomposition), Code and Diagram-to-Code Agents (code synthesis or recovery), and a Check Agent (verification and debugging). Together, the agents enable an iterative, controllable pipeline from textual instructions to structured diagrams.

A Check Agent validates and debugs the code, compares rendered outputs against the specification, and drives an iterative feedback loop—supporting end-to-end Diagram Generation, Diagram Coding, and Diagram Editing.

question:
I am preparing a figure for my paper to illustrate the following framework:
This diagram presents the pipeline of the proposed **StyleMaster**, which performs video stylization guided by a style image and a textual description.

The framework is composed of the following major components:

1. **Input & Output**:
   - The input is a raw video and a style image (e.g., Van Gogh painting).
   - The output is a stylized video with artistic consistency.

2. **Style Extraction**:
   - The style image is encoded using a **CLIP image encoder** to extract patch-level features and image embeddings.
   - Patches with lower similarity to the accompanying text prompt (e.g., "A lone penguin walks on a sandy beach at sunset.") are selected for style representation.
   - A local selection module (Q-Former) refines these patches.
   - A **global projection module** transforms them into global style tokens using contrastive learning, enhanced with specially constructed data pairs.

3. **Contrastive Dataset Construction**:
   - Positive pairs are created by rearranging anchor images.
   - Negative samples are synthesized via **model illusion** from arbitrary text-to-image models.

4. **Stylization Network (DiT Block)**:
   - A spatial-temporal diffusion transformer (DiT) applies multiple blocks of self-attention and cross-attention.
   - Style and text features are injected via decoupled cross-attention modules.
   - A motion adapter handles temporal consistency.

5. **Gray Tile ControlNet**:
   - Ensures better content preservation and stylization control.

Please generate:
 1. A visual diagram that clearly shows the pipeline from video and style image input to stylized video output.
 2. A separate caption summarizing the figure. Please provide the image and caption separately.
reference_text: The pipeline of our proposed StyleMaster. We first obtain patch features and image embedding of the style image from CLIP, then we select the patches sharing less similarity with text prompt as texture guidance, and use a global projection module to transform it into global style descriptions. The global projection module is trained with a contrastive dataset constructed by model illusion through contrastive learning. The style information is then injected into the model through the decoupled cross-attention. The motion adapter and gray tile ControlNet are used to enhance dynamic quality and enable content control respectively.
generated_text: StyleMaster pipeline. A CLIP-based style extractor selects low text-aligned patches from the reference style image, refines them with a Q-Former, and projects them via contrastive learning into global style tokens trained with positives (rearranged anchors) and negatives (model-illusion samples). A spatial–temporal DiT injects text and style through decoupled cross-attention and a motion adapter for temporal consistency. A Gray Tile ControlNet conditions the diffusion to preserve content and control stylization, producing a coherent stylized video.

question: What are the internal parts of an earthworm and how do they function? Use the image to explain.
reference_text: Earthworms have a segmented body with a complete digestive system, a brain, ventral nerve cord, and hearts that pump blood. They are hermaphrodites with both reproductive organs.
generated_text:
Text (what the main parts do):
1.	Mouth/Prostomium – scoops soil‐organic matter into the mouth.
2.	Pharynx – muscular “suction pump” that pulls food in and lubricates it with mucus.
3.	Esophagus – narrow tube that carries food posteriorly.
4.	Crop – thin-walled storage sac; temporarily holds food.
5.	Gizzard – thick, muscular grinder; uses sand/grit to pulverize food.
6.	Intestine – long absorptive tube where enzymes finish digestion and nutrients are absorbed into blood.
7.	Typhlosole – inward fold of the intestinal wall that increases surface area for absorption.
8.	Dorsal blood vessel – main longitudinal vessel that carries blood anteriorly (toward the head).
9.	Ventral blood vessel – returns blood posteriorly; supplies segmental vessels.
10.	Aortic arches (“hearts”) – muscular loops that pump blood from dorsal to ventral vessels, maintaining pressure.
11.	Cerebral ganglion (brain) – small paired nerve center above the pharynx; coordinates movement and behavior.
12.	Ventral nerve cord & segmental ganglia – the worm’s “spinal cord”; relays signals to/from each segment for coordinated crawling.
13.	Nephridia – paired coiled tubes in most segments that remove nitrogenous waste and regulate salts/water (excretory system).
14.	Seminal vesicles – sacs that store sperm produced by the testes before mating.
15.	Seminal receptacles – receive and store sperm from a partner during mating.
16.	Ovaries/Oviducts – produce eggs and release them to be packaged later in a cocoon.
17.	Anus – eliminates indigestible material; castings enrich soil.

How it all works together (quick flow):
Food goes mouth → pharynx → esophagus → crop → gizzard → intestine (typhlosole boosts absorption) → anus. The closed circulatory system (dorsal/ventral vessels + aortic arches) distributes oxygen and nutrients. The nervous system (brain + ventral nerve cord) synchronizes peristalsis and bristle (setae) use for locomotion. Nephridia in each segment handle waste and water balance. As hermaphrodites, earthworms exchange sperm; the clitellum (external band, not shown) later secretes a cocoon where eggs and stored sperm unite and develop. ￼

question: What information is shown in a nuclear symbol? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram shows the nuclear symbol for Boron. The atomic number, in the lower left, represents the number of protons. The mass number, in the upper left, represents protons plus neutrons. If the atom is an ion, its charge is shown in the upper right. These numbers identify the element and isotope.
generated_text:
# Written explanation (separate from the image)

A nuclear symbol (isotope notation) is written in the form (^{A}_{Z}!X^{q}). It conveys:

* **Element symbol (X)** — which element it is (e.g., C, Cl, U).
* **Atomic number (Z)** — the number of protons in the nucleus. This defines the element.
* **Mass number (A)** — total number of nucleons (protons + neutrons).

  * From this you can **derive neutrons**: (N = A - Z).
* **Charge (q)** (optional) — ionic charge; if omitted, the atom is neutral.

  * From this you can **derive electrons**:

    * If the charge is positive (q=+n), electrons (= Z - n).
    * If the charge is negative (q=-n), electrons (= Z + n).

**Example:** (^{37}_{17}\text{Cl}^{-}) → 17 protons, (37-17=20) neutrons, and (17+1=18) electrons.

*(Your image above illustrates these parts visually.)*

question: What is a ray in optics and what are the main types of rays used in ray diagrams? Please answer with both an image and a written explanation.
reference_text: This diagram shows Ray (optics). In optics, a ray is an idealized model of light, obtained by choosing a line that is perpendicular to the wave fronts of the actual light, and that points in the direction of energy flow. Rays are used to model the propagation of light through an optical system by dividing the real light field up into discrete rays that can be computationally propagated through the system by the techniques of ray tracing. All three rays should meet at the same point. The Principal Ray or Chief Ray in an optical system is the meridional ray that starts at the edge of the object and passes through the center of the aperture stop. This ray crosses the optical axis at the locations of the pupils. The Central Ray is perpendicular to infrared radiation. The Focal Ray is drawn from the tip of the object through (or towards) the focal point, reflecting off the mirror parallel to the principal axis.
generated_text:
# Written explanation

**What is a ray (in optics)?**
A ray is an idealized line that shows the direction light energy travels. In geometric optics we treat light as straight-line rays that are perpendicular to wavefronts and that obey the rules of **reflection** (angle in = angle out) and **refraction** (Snell’s law) at boundaries.

**Main types of rays you see in ray diagrams**

1. **Incident ray** – the incoming ray that strikes a surface or boundary.
2. **Reflected ray** – the ray that bounces off a mirror; its angle to the normal equals the incident angle.
3. **Refracted (transmitted) ray** – the ray that passes into a new medium and bends according to Snell’s law.
4. **Principal rays** – standard, easy-to-trace rays used to locate images with thin lenses and spherical mirrors:

* **For thin lenses**

  * **Parallel (P) ray:** parallel to the principal axis; after the lens it passes through the focal point (F) (converging lens) or appears to come from (F) (diverging lens).
  * **Focal (F) ray:** aimed toward the focal point before the lens; emerges parallel to the axis (roles swap for diverging lenses).
  * **Central/Chief (O) ray:** passes through the optical center and continues essentially undeviated.

* **For spherical mirrors**

  * **Parallel (P) ray:** parallel to the axis; reflects through (F) (concave) or appears to come from (F) behind the mirror (convex).
  * **Focal (F) ray:** goes through (F); reflects parallel to the axis.
  * **Center-of-curvature (C) ray:** goes through the center of curvature; reflects back on itself.

In diagrams, **solid lines** usually show real rays; **dashed extensions** show virtual rays that appear to originate from a point.

question: I don’t fully get how carbon from plants ends up in fossil fuels or the atmosphere. Can you diagram the full carbon cycle and explain each step? Provide an image and explain.
reference_text: This diagram shows the carbon cycle. Here are examples of how carbon moves through human, animal, and plant activity. All living things contain carbon, as do the ocean, air, rocks, and underground fossil fuels, which are made in a process that takes millions of years. Plants take in sunlight and carbon dioxide, and create energy through photosynthesis. When they decay, and are buried underground, plants and other organisms turn into fossil fuel. When we burn fossil fuels, carbon dioxide is quickly released into the air. Plants can also release carbon dioxide just like animals do, through respiration.
generated_text:
# Image — Full Carbon Cycle

*(See the generated diagram above.)*

# Explanation — How carbon moves, and how plant carbon ends up in fossil fuels or the air

**Big picture:** Carbon moves through two intertwined loops.

* The **fast (biological) cycle** shuttles carbon among the atmosphere, living things, soils, and the upper ocean (timescales: days to centuries).
* The **slow (geologic) cycle** locks carbon into rocks and fossil fuels and returns it via tectonics and volcanoes (millennia to millions of years).
  Human activities overlay both, rapidly moving long-stored carbon back to the air.

## 1) Atmosphere ↔ Land (plants, animals, soils)

1. **Photosynthesis (atmosphere → plants):** Plants take in CO₂ and build sugars/biomass.
2. **Respiration (plants & animals → atmosphere):** Almost everything that burns those sugars releases CO₂ back.
3. **Herbivory & food webs:** Plant carbon moves to animals; their respiration returns CO₂.
4. **Death & detritus (plants/animals → soils):** Litter and carcasses enter soils.
5. **Decomposition:**

   * **With oxygen (oxic):** Microbes break biomass down, releasing **CO₂**.
   * **Low-oxygen/anaerobic (wetlands, bogs, sediments):** Microbes produce **CH₄ (methane)**, which later oxidizes in the air to CO₂.
6. **Fire:** Wildfires rapidly convert biomass to CO₂ (and some CH₄/black carbon); regrowth can re-absorb CO₂ over years to decades.
7. **Soil storage:** Some carbon becomes stable **soil organic matter** (humus), persisting from years to centuries unless disturbed (e.g., tillage, warming, drought).

## 2) Atmosphere ↔ Ocean

1. **Gas exchange:** CO₂ dissolves into and out of the **surface ocean** depending on temperature, winds, and concentration gradients.
2. **Carbonate chemistry:** In seawater, CO₂ forms **carbonic acid ↔ bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻) ↔ carbonate (CO₃²⁻)**. Most ocean carbon is stored as bicarbonate/carbonate, buffering the atmosphere.
3. **Biological pump:** Phytoplankton photosynthesize; part of their organic matter and the **CaCO₃ shells** from calcifying organisms sink, carrying carbon to the **deep ocean**. Much is respired at depth (CO₂ stored for decades–centuries) and later **upwells** back to the surface and air.

## 3) Route from plant carbon → **fossil fuels** (slow cycle)

Only a tiny fraction of plant carbon escapes decomposition and fire:

1. **Rapid burial in anoxic settings:** In swamps, peatlands, deltas, or marine muds, dead plant/algal matter is buried faster than it decays. Low oxygen slows microbes.
2. **Diagenesis & maturation (heat + pressure + time):**

   * **Terrestrial plants → peat → lignite → coal.**
   * **Marine algae/zooplankton → organic-rich muds → kerogen → oil & natural gas.**
3. **Geologic storage:** These hydrocarbons remain trapped in rocks for millions of years unless exposed, uplifted, or extracted.

## 4) Weathering, rocks, and volcanoes (slow geologic loop)

1. **Silicate weathering (atmosphere → rivers → ocean):** CO₂ in rainwater forms weak acid that weathers rocks; dissolved bicarbonate flows to the ocean.
2. **Carbonate formation:** Marine organisms and chemistry turn bicarbonate into **limestone/dolomite (CaCO₃/MgCO₃)** that gets buried as rock.
3. **Subduction & degassing:** Tectonics carry carbonates and organic sediments into the mantle; **volcanoes** and metamorphism return CO₂ to the atmosphere.

## 5) Human accelerators

* **Fossil fuel extraction & combustion → atmosphere:** Moves carbon from the slow reservoir (coal/oil/gas) to the fast one as CO₂.
* **Cement production:** Releases CO₂ when limestone is calcined.
* **Deforestation & land-use change:** Reduces photosynthetic uptake and releases stored biomass/soil carbon.
* **Methane leaks & agriculture:** Add CH₄, which later becomes CO₂.
* **Permafrost thaw/peatland drainage:** Frees long-stored organic carbon as CO₂/CH₄.
* **Ocean uptake & acidification:** Extra atmospheric CO₂ drives more dissolution, shifting seawater chemistry and affecting calcifiers.

## 6) Direct answers to your two “where does plant carbon go?” questions

* **Into the atmosphere:** through plant/animal **respiration**, **microbial decay** (CO₂/CH₄), **fires**, and **human burning** of biomass or extracted fossil fuels.
* **Into fossil fuels:** when dead plant (or algal) material is **rapidly buried in oxygen-poor sediments**, then **cooked by heat and pressure** for **geologic timescales**, transforming into **coal (mainly land plants)** or **oil/gas (mainly marine algae/zooplankton)**.

If you’d like, I can tailor a simpler “student cheat-sheet” version or add typical timescales and example environments for each arrow.

question: I'm learning about convolutional neural networks. Can you show how a CNN layer processes an image and what a neuron does in that context?
reference_text: An example input volume is shown in red (e.g. a 32x32x3 CIFAR-10 image), and an example volume of neurons in the first Convolutional layer is shown in blue. Each neuron in this layer is connected only to a local spatial region in the input volume, but spans the full depth (i.e. all color channels). There are multiple neurons (5 in this example) along the depth, each using a different filter. These neurons share the same receptive field but not weights. On the right, a neuron is depicted using the standard neural network model: it computes a weighted sum of inputs followed by a non-linearity (activation function), with connectivity restricted spatially in CNNs.
generated_text:
Alright, here’s how a CNN layer processes an image:

1. **Input Image**: A CNN starts with an image, which is represented as a matrix of pixel values. Each pixel has color channels (e.g., RGB).

2. **Convolution Operation**: In a CNN layer, a small matrix called a filter (or kernel) slides over the image. This filter performs a dot product between itself and the section of the image it’s currently covering. It moves across the entire image, extracting features like edges, textures, or patterns.

3. **Neurons**: Each neuron in the CNN layer corresponds to one region of the image processed by the filter. After the filter slides over an area of the image, the result of the convolution is passed to a neuron, which computes the weighted sum of the values and then applies an activation function (like ReLU).

4. **Activation**: After the neuron processes the result, it passes the output to the next layer or saves it for further processing.

question: I'm studying BERT and I'm confused about how its architecture differs from other Transformer models. Can you generate an image and explain its encoder-only structure?
reference_text: BERT is based on the Transformer encoder architecture. It uses only the encoder stack (unlike models like GPT, which use only the decoder). Each input token is first converted into a dense vector through embedding, combined with positional encodings to maintain word order. These are passed through multiple layers of multi-head self-attention and feed-forward networks, with layer normalization and residual connections. At the top, a linear layer and softmax are used to produce probabilities for tasks like masked word prediction or classification.

The structure starts with input embeddings, where the input tokens are first converted into vectors. These embeddings are then passed through a series of encoder layers (12 in the base version of BERT). Each encoder layer consists of multi-head self-attention and feedforward neural networks that allow the model to understand the contextual relationships between words in a sentence.

This encoder-only setup allows BERT to effectively understand bidirectional context, meaning it can look at the words on both sides of a token during training, unlike traditional unidirectional models. This is what makes BERT so powerful for tasks like question answering and sentence classification.

question: I'm studying GRUs. How are the reset gate and update gate computed in a GRU model, and what role do they play in controlling memory flow? Please explain using the diagram.
reference_text: In a GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit), two key gates control information flow: the reset gate \( R_t \) and the update gate \( Z_t \). Both gates are computed from the current input \( X_t \) and the previous hidden state \( H_{t-1} \) using fully connected layers followed by a sigmoid activation. The reset gate determines how much past information to forget, while the update gate decides how much of the new hidden state will be kept versus carried over from the past. This figure illustrates how both gates are computed in parallel by concatenating \( X_t \) and \( H_{t-1} \), passing them through separate linear layers and activation functions. The sigmoid ensures outputs between 0 and 1, enabling fine-grained control over memory flow.
generated_text:
# Image

A schematic diagram of a single GRU cell at time t has been generated above.

# Text explanation (concise)

**Gate computations**

* **Update gate**
  $z_t = \sigma(W_z x_t + U_z h_{t-1} + b_z)$
  Learns, per dimension, how much of the *previous* state to carry forward.

* **Reset gate**
  $r_t = \sigma(W_r x_t + U_r h_{t-1} + b_r)$
  Learns how much of the *previous* state to expose when forming the new content.

**Candidate hidden state**

* $\tilde{h}_t = \tanh\!\big(W_h x_t + U_h (r_t \odot h_{t-1}) + b_h\big)$
  Here the reset gate $r_t$ gates $h_{t-1}$ before it mixes with the input, letting the unit *forget* irrelevant history (small $r_t$) or reuse it (large $r_t$).

**Final state (memory flow)**

* $h_t = (1 - z_t) \odot \tilde{h}_t + z_t \odot h_{t-1}$
  The update gate $z_t$ interpolates between the old memory and the newly computed candidate:

  * $z_t \approx 1$: keep prior memory $h_{t-1}$ (long-term carry)
  * $z_t \approx 0$: overwrite with $\tilde{h}_t$ (fast update)

**Intuition (mapped to the diagram)**

1. $x_t$ and $h_{t-1}$ feed two sigmoid blocks → $z_t$ and $r_t$.
2. $r_t$ multiplies $h_{t-1}$ (⊙ node) before the tanh block to make $\tilde{h}_t$.
3. A final mixing node blends $\tilde{h}_t$ with $h_{t-1}$ using $1-z_t$ and $z_t$ to produce $h_t$.

**Why it works**

* $r_t$ provides *content-based forgetting* during candidate construction.
* $z_t$ provides *persistent memory* by creating a shortcut for gradients and information from $h_{t-1}$, helping stabilize long-range dependencies without a separate cell state.

question: How to set up a Gmail account? Provide a visual guide and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Go to https://accounts.google.com in a browser. This will open the Google Account sign-in page. If you already have a Google account, you’ll need to sign out before you can continue. 2. Click Create account . You’ll find this small blue link near the bottom of the page, next to the Next button. 3. Select your account type from the menu. A menu will pop up with a few options to choose from. Select either For my personal use , For my child , or For work or my business . If you’re trying to create a business account, you might want to consider signing up for a Google Workspace account instead. The process for creating a child’s account is very similar to creating a personal account for yourself. You’ll need to provide information such as your child’s name, birthdate, and desired email address. However, you’ll also need to sign in with your Gmail account to provide parental consent for their account. 4. Enter your first and last name. Type your first name into the "First name" text box, then enter your last name in the "Last name" box underneath it. You must enter a first name, but the last name is optional. If you're creating a Gmail account for a friend or a child, enter their information in the fields provided. 5. Enter your birth date and gender. On the next page, you’ll be prompted to provide your birthdate (month, day, and year) and gender. If you don’t identify as male or female, select Custom to see additional options. You can also select Rather not say . Click Next when you’re done. Google asks for your birthdate because some Google services have specific age requirements. Google may also use this information to personalize your experience. If you decide to provide your gender, Google will use this information to personalize your account—e.g., by using your preferred pronouns in text that refers to you. 6. Select or create a custom email address. On the next page, you’ll be offered some automatically generated email addresses based on your name. If you don’t want any of those, select Create your own Gmail address and type in your preferred username. You can use a combination of letters, numbers, and periods. This is the text that will appear before “@gmail.com” in your email address. Click Next when you’re done. You must enter a unique username that isn't being used by someone else. If it's taken, you'll see: That username is taken. Try another. If the username you want is taken, add a number at the end or change the spelling. Sometimes Google will reject a username if it’s extremely similar to one that somebody else is using (even if there are slight differences), if someone else had that username in the past and then deleted it, or if Google has reserved the name to prevent abuse or spam. 7. Enter and confirm your new password. Type your preferred password into the "Password" text box, then type the same password into the "Confirm" box underneath it. Check the Show password box to see what you are typing. Click Next when you’re done. These passwords must match before you can proceed. Make sure to use a strong password to avoid any unauthorized access to your account. 8. Enter a recovery email. Google will contact you at your recovery email address if something goes wrong with your new account—e.g. if you get locked out or Google detects unusual activity from your address. Click Next when you’re done. If you don’t have an alternate email, or if you’d rather set up recovery options later, click Skip . 9. Review your info and select Next . On the next page, you’ll see your new account name and email address. If it looks good, click Next . Otherwise, you can use your browser’s Back button to go back and make changes to the information you entered in the previous steps. 10. Agree to the Terms of Service. On the next page, you’ll be prompted to agree to Google’s terms and privacy policy. Once you’ve reviewed them, click I agree . If you change your mind, click Cancel instead. 11. Confirm your personalization options. A window will pop up asking if you want to agree to Google’s personalization options. Click Confirm to continue, or select More options to change your settings. 12. Customize your account settings. Once you verify your new address, you’ll be taken to the Google Account home page. From here, you can adjust settings such as: Your account recovery information. Add a recovery email here if you didn’t already, or add a phone number so you have two recovery options. Set a home address for a more personalized experience. For example, Google will show you weather reports and map results based on your address. Adjust your privacy and security settings and review privacy recommendations for your account. Add contacts or set up a family group. 13. Go to https://mail.google.com to access your Gmail. You should be automatically logged into your new account. If not, you’ll be prompted to sign in. The first time you visit this page, you’ll see options to customize your inbox, set a profile image, and add or import contacts. To write and send an email, click Compose in the top left corner. To see your emails, click the Inbox tab on the left side of the page. Use the tabs at the top of your inbox on the right to view different categories such as regular emails (in Primary ), marketing related emails (in Promotions ), or email notifications from various social media platforms (in Social ). In the menu on the left, you can also browse your drafts, sent emails, scheduled messages, your spam folder, and more. Adjust your settings by clicking the Settings icon at the top right side of the page. To sign out of your account, tap your initial or profile picture at the top right corner of the page, then select Sign Out .

# Text steps (Android)

> Works on most Android phones. Names can vary a little by brand (e.g., **Pixel/Google Phone** vs **Samsung One UI**).

## A) Fastest way — from Recents

1. Open the **Phone** app.
2. Tap **Recents** (or **Call history**).
3. Tap the number (or the **ⓘ / Details** icon).
4. Choose **Block/report spam** (Samsung: **Block** or **Block number**).
5. (Optional) Check **Report as spam**, then tap **Block** to confirm.

## B) Add a number manually (no recent call)

* **Pixel / Google Phone:** Phone app → **⋮** (top-right) → **Settings** → **Blocked numbers** → **Add a number** → enter it → **Block**.
* **Samsung:** Phone app → **⋮** → **Settings** → **Block numbers** → **Add phone number** (or toggle **Block unknown/private numbers**) → **+**/**Add**.

## C) Block a saved contact

1. Open the **Contacts** (or in Phone → **Contacts** tab).
2. Open the contact → **⋮** → **Block numbers**/**Block contact** → **Block**.

## D) Block texts from Messages (optional)

* **Google Messages:** Open the conversation → **⋮** → **Details** → **Block & report spam** → **Block**.
* **Samsung Messages:** Open the thread → **⋮** → **Block number** → **Block**.

## Unblock later

* Go back to **Phone app → Settings → Blocked numbers** (Samsung: **Block numbers**) and remove the entry, or open the contact and tap **Unblock**.

---

# Screenshots (generated)

See the images above: they illustrate the quick block from **Recents**, the **Block/report spam** menu, the **Block number?** confirmation, and the **Blocked numbers** settings page.
",

question: How to Turn Off Your iPhone? Provide visual steps and text the steps.
reference_text: 1. Press and hold a volume button and the right side button simultaneously. It doesn't matter which volume button you press. After holding down these buttons for a few seconds, a slider will appear on the screen. If you don't hold down long enough, you might take a screenshot . 2. Drag the slider to the right. This powers off your iPhone. It can take up to 30 seconds for your iPhone to power down. 3. Press and hold the right side button to turn the iPhone back on. You can lift your finger from the button once the Apple logo appears. You may need to wait a few moments until you can use your iPhone . If your device is unresponsive, you can perform a hard reset .
generated_text:
Here are the steps—first the visuals, then the text.

# Visual Steps (image)

*(Infographic above shows both methods: buttons and Settings.)*

# Text Steps

## Method 1 — Using the buttons

1. On iPhones with **Face ID** (no Home button): **press and hold the Side button + either Volume button** together until the **“slide to power off”** slider appears.
   On older iPhones with a **Home button** (Touch ID): **press and hold the Side (or Top) button** until the slider appears.

2. **Drag the slider to the right** to power off.

3. **Wait** a few seconds until the screen turns completely black.

4. (Optional) **Turn it back on**: press and hold the **Side button** until you see the Apple logo.

> Tip: If you keep holding the buttons after the slider appears, some models may start **Emergency SOS**. If that happens, release the buttons and cancel SOS, then try again.

## Method 2 — Using the Settings app (works even if buttons are broken)

1. Open **Settings** → **General**.
2. Scroll down and tap **Shut Down**.
3. **Slide to power off**.

That’s it!
",
